title: Unit 2 Checkpoint: Derivatives Definition & Rules
description: Skills quiz (differentiation rules) + conceptual quiz (interpretation). Covers derivative definition, differentiability, power/product/quotient rules, trig/exp/log derivatives, and derivatives from graphs/tables.

remediationStrategy.description: Students scoring below threshold receive focused reteaching before advancing to Unit 3 (Chain Rule, Implicit Differentiation).

clusters.reteachFocus: Both forms of limit definition, computing derivatives from definition
Power rule fluency, product/quotient rule application, rewriting before differentiating
Estimating derivatives from tables, reading slope from graphs, interpreting in context

assessmentProblems.question: Use the limit definition to find f'(x) for f(x) = 3x² - 2x + 1.
The function f satisfies lim(h→0) [f(3+h) - f(3)]/h = 7. What does this tell you?
assessmentProblems.answer: f'(3) = 7. The derivative of f at x=3 is 7. This means the slope of the tangent line to f at x=3 is 7, and the instantaneous rate of change of f at x=3 is 7.

assessmentProblems.question: At which x-values is f(x) = |x² - 4| not differentiable? Explain why.
assessmentProblems.answer: Not differentiable at x = -2 and x = 2. At these points, x²-4 = 0, and the absolute value creates corners (the graph has sharp turns where x²-4 changes sign).

assessmentProblems.question: The table shows: t = 0, 2, 5, 8, 12 with f(t) = 10, 18, 30, 26, 14. Estimate f'(5) using the values in the table.
assessmentProblems.answer: Use average of slopes on either side: f'(5) ≈ [f(8)-f(2)]/(8-2) = (26-18)/6 = 8/6 = 4/3 ≈ 1.33. (Or symmetric difference quotient.)

assessmentProblems.question: The graph of f is shown with f increasing and concave down on (0, 3), reaching a maximum at x=3, then decreasing on (3, 6). Sketch the graph of f' on [0, 6].
assessmentProblems.answer: f' is positive on (0, 3) and negative on (3, 6). f' crosses zero at x=3. Since f is concave down throughout, f' is decreasing. So f' starts positive, decreases through zero at x=3, and continues decreasing (becomes more negative).
